---
 Genes operate in conjunction with one another in specific contexts to execute their functions. Gaining a mechanistic understanding of expression regulation across various conditions is crucial for deciphering how these genes influence complex traits and for developing new therapies. While transcriptome-wide association studies have shed light on the role of individual genes in disease-relevant mechanisms, modern models suggest that gene-gene interactions significantly contribute to disease etiology and progression. In this study, we introduce PhenoPLIER, a computational approach that maps gene-trait associations and pharmacological perturbation data into a common latent representation for joint analysis. This representation is based on modules of genes with similar expression patterns across the same conditions. Our results demonstrate that diseases are significantly associated with gene modules expressed in relevant cell types. Moreover, PhenoPLIER accurately predicts known drug-disease pairs and infer mechanisms of action. Using a CRISPR screen to analyze lipid regulation, we discovered that functionally important players lacking individual gene associations are prioritized in trait-associated modules by PhenoPLIER. In conclusion, by incorporating groups of co-expressed genes, PhenoPLIER can contextualize genetic associations and reveal potential targets that may have been overlooked by single-gene strategies. This novel framework for interpreting genetic associations through the lens of gene modules provides a new perspective on disease etiology and drug mechanisms.

Keywords: Genetic studies, Functional genomics, Gene co-expression, Therapeutic targets, Drug repurposing, Clustering of complex traits.

 In the field of genetic studies, a comprehensive understanding of how genes interact to influence complex traits is critical for elucidating disease etiology and identifying therapeutic targets. While transcriptome-wide association studies have been successful in uncovering individual gene associations with disease-relevant mechanisms, they do not account for the important role of gene-gene interactions. Here, we present PhenoPLIER, a novel computational approach that maps gene-trait associations and pharmacological perturbation data into a common latent representation based on modules of genes with similar expression patterns across relevant conditions. Our results demonstrate that diseases are significantly associated with specific gene modules, and PhenoPLIER can accurately predict known drug-disease pairs and infer mechanisms of action. Moreover, we find that functionally important players lacking individual gene associations are prioritized in trait-associated modules by PhenoPLIER. Therefore, by incorporating groups of co-expressed genes, PhenoPLIER provides a new framework for interpreting genetic associations and reveals potential targets that may have been missed by single-gene strategies, ultimately moving the broader field of functional genomics forward.

 In the field of genetic studies, uncovering the relationship between genes and complex traits is critical for understanding disease etiology and identifying novel therapeutic targets. While transcriptome-wide association studies have shed light on individual gene-trait associations, they fail to capture the intricate gene-gene interactions that contribute to trait architecture. Here, we present PhenoPLIER, a computational approach that integrates gene-trait associations and pharmacological perturbation data into a common latent space based on co-expressed gene modules. We demonstrate that diseases are significantly associated with specific gene modules expressed in relevant cell types, and our approach accurately predicts known drug-disease pairs and infer mechanisms of action. Moreover, by incorporating co-expressed genes, PhenoPLIER reveals functionally important players lacking individual gene-trait associations, thereby highlighting potential targets that may be missed by traditional single-gene strategies. Our findings underscore the importance of considering gene-gene interactions in genetic studies and provide a novel framework for interpreting genetic associations through the lens of gene modules, paving the way for improved drug repurposing and therapeutic target identification in complex traits.

Transcriptome-wide association studies have been instrumental in uncovering the role of individual genes in disease-relevant mechanisms.  In the field of genetic studies, a comprehensive understanding of how genes influence complex traits is crucial for elucidating disease etiology and identifying novel therapeutic targets. While transcriptome-wide association studies have shed light on individual gene contributions to disease-relevant mechanisms, there is a growing recognition that gene-gene interactions play a significant role in the origin and progression of complex traits (context). To address this gap, we introduce PhenoPLIER, a computational approach that maps gene-trait associations and pharmacological perturbation data into a common latent representation based on modules of genes with similar expression patterns across relevant conditions (content). We demonstrate that diseases are significantly associated with these gene modules, and our approach accurately predicts known drug-disease pairs and infers mechanisms of action. Furthermore, we find that functionally important players lacking individual genetic associations are prioritized in trait-associated modules by PhenoPLIER, highlighting its ability to reveal potential targets missed by single-gene strategies (content). By incorporating groups of co-expressed genes, PhenoPLIER provides a novel framework for interpreting genetic associations through the lens of gene modules, thereby contextualizing genetic associations and facilitating the identification of new therapeutic opportunities (conclusion). Our work underscores the importance of considering gene-gene interactions in functional genomics and drug repurposing efforts for complex traits.

 In this manuscript, we present PhenoPLIER, a novel computational method that integrates gene-trait associations and pharmacological perturbation data into a shared latent space for comprehensive analysis. Genes function in a coordinated manner within specific contexts to execute their roles. Gaining a mechanistic understanding of expression regulation across various conditions is vital for elucidating the influence of these genes on complex traits, which is critical for developing effective therapies. Although transcriptome-wide association studies have contributed significantly to uncovering individual gene contributions to disease-relevant mechanisms, modern genetic research suggests that gene-gene interactions play a pivotal role in disease etiology and progression.

PhenoPLIER's methodology relies on the representation of genes with similar expression patterns across comparable conditions as modules. Our findings reveal that diseases are significantly associated with these gene modules, particularly when expressed in relevant cell types. The approach demonstrates high accuracy in predicting known drug-disease pairs and inferring mechanisms of action.

Furthermore, our analysis of a CRISPR screen for lipid regulation reveals that functionally important players lacking individual gene associations are prioritized within trait-associated modules by PhenoPLIER. By incorporating groups of co-expressed genes, PhenoPLIER offers the ability to contextualize genetic associations and uncover potential therapeutic targets that might otherwise be overlooked through conventional single-gene strategies.

In summary, PhenoPLIER provides a novel framework for interpreting genetic associations via gene modules, enabling researchers to reveal novel insights into disease etiology and drug mechanisms through the lens of functional genomics and gene co-expression. The approach has promising implications for therapeutic target identification and drug repurposing.
column2: [PASS] (1.00)  The field of genetic studies has made significant strides in identifying individual gene-trait associations, yet a comprehensive understanding of how genes act in concert to influence complex traits remains elusive. Existing methods such as transcriptome-wide association studies have been successful in uncovering the role of individual genes in disease-relevant mechanisms, but they fail to account for the intricate gene-gene interactions that are critical for understanding disease etiology and progression. Here, we introduce PhenoPLIER, a novel computational approach that maps gene-trait associations and pharmacological perturbation data into a common latent representation for joint analysis. Our method is based on the formation of modules comprising genes with similar expression patterns across various conditions, allowing us to identify significant associations between diseases and these gene modules in relevant cell types. We demonstrate the accuracy of PhenoPLIER in predicting known drug-disease pairs and inferring mechanisms of action. Furthermore, we highlight the utility of our approach by identifying functionally important players that lack individual gene-trait associations but are prioritized within trait-associated modules using a CRISPR screen to analyze lipid regulation. In conclusion, PhenoPLIER provides a novel framework for interpreting genetic associations through the lens of gene co-expression, highlighting potential therapeutic targets that may have been missed by single-gene strategies and advancing our understanding of functional genomics and drug repurposing in the context of complex traits.

 In this manuscript, we present PhenoPLIER, a novel computational approach that integrates gene-trait associations and pharmacological perturbation data into a unified latent space for comprehensive analysis. Genes often function in coordination with each other within specific contexts to execute their roles. A mechanistic understanding of expression regulation across various conditions is essential to elucidate how these genes influence complex traits, which is vital for developing effective therapies. While transcriptome-wide association studies have contributed significantly to identifying individual genes associated with disease-relevant mechanisms, recent genetic models suggest that gene-gene interactions play a pivotal role in the onset and progression of complex traits. Utilizing a CRISPR screen to analyze lipid regulation, we discovered that functionally important genes lacking individual associations are prioritized within trait-associated modules by PhenoPLIER. In conclusion, PhenoPLIER's incorporation of co-expressed gene groups enables the contextualization of genetic associations and reveals potential targets that may be overlooked using single-gene strategies. Our approach offers a fresh perspective for interpreting genetic associations through the lens of gene modules, providing new avenues for therapeutic target identification and drug repurposing.

 The field of genetic studies has made significant strides in understanding the relationship between individual genes and complex traits, yet there remains a gap in our knowledge regarding the role of gene-gene interactions in disease etiology and progression. Traditional transcriptome-wide association studies have been successful in uncovering the role of individual genes in disease-relevant mechanisms; however, they do not account for the complex interplay between genes that occurs in specific contexts. Here, we introduce PhenoPLIER, a novel computational approach that maps gene-trait associations and pharmacological perturbation data into a common latent representation based on modules of genes with similar expression patterns across different conditions. Our results demonstrate that diseases are significantly associated with these gene modules expressed in relevant cell types, and PhenoPLIER is accurate in predicting known drug-disease pairs and inferring mechanisms of action. Furthermore, we find that functionally important players lacking individual gene associations are prioritized in trait-associated modules by PhenoPLIER. Therefore, by incorporating groups of co-expressed genes, PhenoPLIER can contextualize genetic associations and reveal potential targets missed by single-gene strategies. This novel framework for interpreting genetic associations through the lens of gene modules not only advances our understanding of the complex relationship between genetics and disease but also has implications for drug repurposing and the development of new therapies.

PhenoPLIER provides a novel framework for interpreting genetic associations through the lens of gene modules.

 In this manuscript, we present PhenoPLIER, a novel computational method that integrates gene-trait associations and pharmacological perturbation data into a unified latent space for comprehensive analysis. Genes operate in a coordinated manner within specific contexts to execute their functions. A mechanistic understanding of expression regulation across various conditions is essential to elucidate how these genes influence complex traits, which is critical for developing new therapies. While transcriptome-wide association studies have contributed significantly to our understanding of individual genes' roles in disease-relevant mechanisms, contemporary models of complex trait architecture suggest that gene-gene interactions are vital in disease etiology and progression.

The foundation of PhenoPLIER lies in the representation of gene modules with similar expression patterns across comparable conditions. Our findings indicate that diseases exhibit significant associations with gene modules expressed in relevant cell types. Moreover, our approach accurately predicts known drug-disease pairs and infer mechanisms of action. Through a CRISPR screen analyzing lipid regulation, we discovered that functionally important genes lacking individual associations are prioritized in trait-associated modules by PhenoPLIER.

In summary, PhenoPLIER's innovative approach of incorporating co-expressed gene groups enables the contextualization of genetic associations and reveals potential targets overlooked by single-gene strategies. By providing a new framework for interpreting genetic associations through the lens of gene modules, PhenoPLIER offers valuable insights into disease etiology and drug mechanisms, paving the way for therapeutic target identification and drug repurposing.

 Genes function in a coordinated manner within specific contexts to execute their roles. A comprehensive understanding of how these genes influence complex traits necessitates insights into expression regulation across diverse conditions. Such knowledge is critical for the development of novel therapies. While transcriptome-wide association studies have been instrumental in uncovering the individual gene-disease associations, modern models suggest that gene-gene interactions significantly contribute to disease etiology and progression. In this study, we introduce PhenoPLIER, a computational approach that integrates gene-trait associations and pharmacological perturbation data into a unified latent space for joint analysis. This framework is based on modules of genes with comparable expression patterns across the same conditions. Our results indicate that diseases are significantly associated with gene modules expressed in relevant cell types. Moreover, PhenoPLIER accurately predicts known drug-disease pairs and infer mechanisms of action. Furthermore, we demonstrate the utility of PhenoPLIER using a CRISPR screen to analyze lipid regulation. Our findings suggest that functionally important genes, which lack individual associations, can be prioritized in trait-associated modules by PhenoPLIER.

Keywords: Genetic studies, Functional genomics, Gene co-expression, Therapeutic targets, Drug repurposing, Clustering of complex traits.

column2: [PASS] (1.00)  In the field of genetic studies, a comprehensive understanding of how genes act in concert to influence complex traits is crucial for elucidating disease etiology and identifying therapeutic targets. While transcriptome-wide association studies have shed light on individual gene-trait associations, modern models suggest that gene-gene interactions play a significant role in disease origin and progression. To address this gap, we present PhenoPLIER, a novel computational approach that maps gene-trait associations and pharmacological perturbation data into a common latent representation for joint analysis. This representation is based on modules of genes with similar expression patterns across relevant conditions. Our results demonstrate that diseases are significantly associated with specific gene modules, and PhenoPLIER accurately predicts known drug-disease pairs and infers mechanisms of action. Furthermore, we applied PhenoPLIER to a CRISPR screen analyzing lipid regulation, revealing that functionally important players lacking individual gene-trait associations are prioritized in trait-associated modules by our approach. This research highlights the potential of functional genomics and gene co-expression analysis in uncovering novel therapeutic targets and facilitating drug repurposing for complex traits.
column3: genetic studies, functional genomics, gene co-expression, therapeutic targets, drug repurposing, clustering of complex traits
column4: Genes act in concert with each other in specific contexts to perform their functions. Determining how these genes influence complex traits requires a mechanistic understanding of expression regulation across different conditions. It has been shown that this insight is critical for developing new therapies. Transcriptome-wide association studies have helped uncover the role of individual genes in disease-relevant mechanisms. However, modern models of the architecture of complex traits predict that gene-gene interactions play a crucial role in disease origin and progression. Here we introduce PhenoPLIER, a computational approach that maps gene-trait associations and pharmacological perturbation data into a common latent representation for a joint analysis. This representation is based on modules of genes with similar expression patterns across the same conditions. We observe that diseases are significantly associated with gene modules expressed in relevant cell types, and our approach is accurate in predicting known drug-disease pairs and inferring mechanisms of action. Furthermore, using a CRISPR screen to analyze lipid regulation, we find that functionally important players lack associations but are prioritized in trait-associated modules by PhenoPLIER.

column6: Projecting genetic associations through gene expression patterns highlights disease etiology and drug mechanisms

column1: [PASS] (1.00)  Genes function in a coordinated manner within specific contexts to execute their roles. Gaining a mechanistic understanding of how these genes regulate complex traits across various conditions is crucial for elucidating disease etiology and developing novel therapies. Although transcriptome-wide association studies have been instrumental in identifying the role of individual genes in disease-relevant mechanisms, modern genetic studies suggest that gene-gene interactions significantly contribute to the origin and progression of complex traits. In this study, we introduce PhenoPLIER, a computational approach that integrates gene-trait associations and pharmacological perturbation data into a unified latent representation for joint analysis. This representation is based on modules of genes with similar expression patterns across identical conditions. We demonstrate that diseases are significantly associated with gene modules expressed in relevant cell types, and our approach accurately predicts known drug-disease pairs and infers mechanisms of action. Moreover, through a CRISPR screen analyzing lipid regulation, we discover that functionally important genes lacking associations are prioritized in trait-associated modules by PhenoPLIER. Our study highlights the importance of incorporating gene-gene interactions in functional genomics and provides insights into drug repurposing and therapeutic targets for complex traits.
column2: [PASS] (1.00)  In the field of genetic studies, a comprehensive understanding of how genes interact to influence complex traits remains an open question. Although transcriptome-wide association studies have shed light on individual gene-trait associations, they do not fully capture the intricate network of gene-gene interactions that contribute to disease etiology and progression. To address this gap, we introduce PhenoPLIER, a novel computational approach that maps gene-trait associations and pharmacological perturbation data into a common latent representation for joint analysis. This representation is based on modules of genes with similar expression patterns across relevant conditions. Our results demonstrate that diseases are significantly associated with specific gene modules, highlighting the importance of gene-gene interactions in disease origin and progression. Furthermore, PhenoPLIER accurately predicts known drug-disease pairs and infer mechanisms of action. Notably, a CRISPR screen analysis of lipid regulation revealed that functionally important players lacking individual gene-trait associations are prioritized in trait-associated modules by PhenoPLIER. These findings emphasize the potential of PhenoPLIER for uncovering novel therapeutic targets and facilitating drug repurposing, ultimately advancing our understanding of complex traits and their underlying mechanisms.

column1: [PASS] (1.00)  Genes function in a coordinated manner within specific contexts to execute their roles. Gaining a mechanistic understanding of expression regulation across various conditions is essential to elucidate how these genes influence complex traits, which is critical for developing novel therapies. While transcriptome-wide association studies have been instrumental in uncovering the role of individual genes in disease-relevant mechanisms, modern perspectives on the architecture of complex traits suggest that gene-gene interactions significantly contribute to disease etiology and progression. In this study, we present PhenoPLIER, a computational approach that integrates gene-trait associations and pharmacological perturbation data into a unified latent space for joint analysis. This common representation is derived from modules of genes with similar expression patterns across identical conditions. Our results indicate that diseases are significantly associated with gene modules expressed in relevant cell types. Moreover, PhenoPLIER accurately predicts known drug-disease pairs and infer mechanisms of action. Utilizing a CRISPR screen to analyze lipid regulation, we discovered that functionally important genes lacking associations are prioritized in trait-associated modules by PhenoPLIER. Therefore, our approach offers a promising strategy for identifying therapeutic targets and repurposing drugs for complex traits.
column2: [PASS] (1.00)  In the field of genetic studies, a comprehensive understanding of how genes work in concert to influence complex traits remains an open research question. While transcriptome-wide association studies have shed light on the role of individual genes in disease-relevant mechanisms, modern models suggest that gene-gene interactions play a crucial role in disease origin and progression. To address this gap, we introduce PhenoPLIER, a computational approach that maps gene-trait associations and pharmacological perturbation data into a common latent representation for joint analysis. Our method is based on modules of genes with similar expression patterns across the same conditions, enabling us to observe significant associations between diseases and gene modules expressed in relevant cell types. We demonstrate the accuracy of our approach by predicting known drug-disease pairs and inferring mechanisms of action. Moreover, using a CRISPR screen to analyze lipid regulation, we find that functionally important players lacking individual gene associations are prioritized in trait-associated modules by PhenoPLIER. Our study highlights the potential of integrating functional genomics and gene co-expression analysis for identifying therapeutic targets and drug repurposing opportunities, ultimately advancing our understanding of disease etiology and drug mechanisms.
